act: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT

type.name: section
type.title: Cases to be tried expeditiously.
type.context: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT under Cases to be tried expeditiously. 3. A case shall be tried as expeditiously as possible in an endeavour to conclude the case within such time as the complexity and the relevant evidence necessitate.
type.description: A case shall be tried as expeditiously as possible in an endeavour to conclude the case within such time as the complexity and the relevant evidence necessitate.

act: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT

type.name: section
type.title: Time limit for decisions in civil cases.
type.context: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT under Time limit for decisions in civil cases. 4.  (1) A Judge who presides at the trial of a civil case shall give a written or an oral decision and reasons for the decision at the conclusion of the hearing of the case or as soon as possible after the conclusion of the hearing but not later than one hundred and twenty days from the date of conclusion of the hearing.  (2) In this section a civil case includes an interlocutory proceeding and a decision includes an interlocutory decision.

description.description: A Judge who presides at the trial of a civil case shall give a written or an oral decision and reasons for the decision at the conclusion of the hearing of the case or as soon as possible after the conclusion of the hearing but not later than one hundred and twenty days from the date of conclusion of the hearing.
In this section a civil case includes an interlocutory proceeding and a decision includes an interlocutory decision.

act: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT

type.name: section
type.title: Time limit for decisions in appeal cases.
type.context: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT under Time limit for decisions in appeal cases. 5. Where the Court of Appeal or the Full Court hears an appeal, a Judge on behalf of the Court or each Judge of the Court shall give a written or an oral decision and reasons for the decision at the conclusion of the hearing of the appeal or as soon as possible after the conclusion of the hearing but not later than thirty days from the date of conclusion of the hearing.
type.description: Where the Court of Appeal or the Full Court hears an appeal, a Judge on behalf of the Court or each Judge of the Court shall give a written or an oral decision and reasons for the decision at the conclusion of the hearing of the appeal or as soon as possible after the conclusion of the hearing but not later than thirty days from the date of conclusion of the hearing.

act: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT

type.name: section
type.title: Persistently failing to write or give decisions.
type.context: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT under Persistently failing to write or give decisions. 6. In accordance with article 197 (3) of the Constitution a Judge may be removed from office for, among other reasons, persistently failing to give written or oral decisions and reasons for the decisions within the time specified in this Act.

description.description: of the Constitution a Judge may be removed from office for, among other reasons, persistently failing to give written or oral decisions and reasons for the decisions within the time specified in this Act.

type.name: section
type.title: Failure to write or give decisions.
type.context: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT under Failure to write or give decisions. 7. Where a Judge fails to write or give an oral decision and reasons for the decision within the time specified in section 4 or 5 or the extended time granted under section 8 the Chancellor shall cause the Registrar to notify the Judge that the Judge has failed to comply with the given time limit and that if the Judge persists in not writing or giving oral decisions as prescribed by this Act, action may be taken under LAWS OF GUYANA Time Limit for Judicial Decisions Cap. 3:13 5  L.R.O. 1/2012      Extension of time in special cases.                                          article 197 of the Constitution with a view to removing the Judge from office.

act: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT

type.name: section
type.title: Extension of time in special cases.
type.context: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT under Extension of time in special cases. 8. (1) If a Judge cannot comply with the time limit in section 4 or 5 then the Judge may apply to the Chancellor for an extension of time.  (2) A Judge shall apply for an extension of time   (a)  in writing;  (b)  not less than twenty-one days before expiration of the specified time limit;  (c)  providing reasons and evidence of any supporting circumstances why the Judge cannot meet the time limit; and  (d) proposing the duration of extension sought.  (3) The Chancellor may grant an extension of time where   (a)  the case is shown to be a complex one;  (b)  the Judge claims to be ill and the illness is supported by a medical certificate;  (c)  the Judge cites as a reason, a claim of additional official assignments;  (d)  no injustice occurs from the grant; or  (e)  any other claim by the Judge is accepted as reasonable.  LAWS OF GUYANA 6 Cap. 3:13 Time Limit for Judicial Decisions  L.R.O. 1/2012                Judge to inform Chancellor  of non-compliance.      Judges report.          Report of the chancellor             (4) Where the Chancellor is satisfied that a Judge is entitled to an extension of time to write or give a decision, the Chancellor shall, by notice in writing, grant an extension of time that is reasonable in the circumstances of the case.  (5) Where the Chancellor is not satisfied that the Judge ought to be granted an extension, the Chancellor shall direct the Judge to give the decision within thirty days beginning from the date of receipt of the intimation from the Chancellor or from the date of expiration of the specified time limit, whichever date is the later.

act: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT

type.name: section
type.title: Judge to inform Chancellor of non-compliance.
type.context: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT under Judge to inform Chancellor of non-compliance. 9. As soon as practicable, but not later than 31st March of the succeeding year, where a Judge has not, in the preceding year, complied with the time limit in section 4 or 5 or the extended time granted under section 8 the Judge shall, through the Registrar of the Supreme Court, inform the Chancellor of the case in which the provision was not complied with.

type.context: TIME LIMIT FOR JUDICIAL DECISIONS ACT    ACT under Judge's report. 10. (2) The time for and contents of the Judge's report may be prescribed.
